newsitem.title: INDIA: INDIAN HEADLINE STOCKS - Factors to watch - April 1.
newsitem.headline: INDIAN HEADLINE STOCKS - Factors to watch - April 1.

text.p: Following are some of the main factors affecting Indian stock markets on Tuesday morning:
** Indian stocks will continue to head lower, shaken by sudden political crisis which erupted with Congress party's withdrawal of crucial support to ruling coalition, traders say
** Shares across the country's bourses fall more than seven percent in nervous trade on Monday as investors struggle to come to grips with the unexpected bout of political uncertainty
** Prime Minister H.D. Deve Gowda gets until April 11 to prove his majority in parliament, a near impossible task after his government loses support of its key ally

** President Shankar Dayal Sharma's instruction to Deve Gowda to seek a vote of confidence by April 11 closes option to call snap polls, forcing him either to resign or seek a split in the fractious Congress party to gain a majority
** Asked how Congress expected to form a government backed by the coalition it sought to topple, spokesman Vithal Gadgil said: "In politics, certain things are not stated publicly."
** Foreign investors in Hong Kong and London return to business after long Easter weekend. Traders say India's overseas listed global depositary receipts (GDRs) will see sharp fall during the day
** India and Pakistan talks end with an agreement to meet again in the Pakistan capital Islamabad. No dates are set.
** Main opposition Bharatiya Janata Party (BJP) says it will not seek to form a fresh government
** Foreign investors despondent at India's sudden plunge into political crisis should watch and wait rather than take any drastic decisions, brokers say
They say it is too early to retreat from India or take advantage of cheap prices and jump in
** Political leaders jockey for power ahead of confidence vote with United Front coalition swiftly closing ranks behind the Prime Minister
** Commerce minister, shrugging off political setback to the government, unveils a new trade policy that lifts import controls on hundreds of items
Bolla Buli Ramaiah also said the rupee, riding on the strength of a surge in foreign exchange reserves, would remain stable despite the political uncertainty
